feed.title: What's a good stopping point? Making the case for the capabilities enabled by CTV+CSFS

entry.title: What's a good stopping point? Making the case for the capabilities enabled by CTV+CSFS
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the potential and underexplored capabilities of commitment hashes like TXHASH in the context of Bitcoin development. A specific primitive that has caught attention is the explicit method of committing to sibling prevouts, which has been a topic of conversation among developers. This method and its implications were further explored in a detailed discussion available at [delvingbitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/how-ctv-csfs-improves-bitvm-bridges/1591/8), highlighting how it could enhance Bitcoin Virtual Machine (BitVM) bridges through improved commitment schemes like CTV CSFS.
The conversation underscores a broader interest in expanding the utility of programmable versions of commitment hashes beyond their current applications, which are primarily limited to single-transaction exogenous fees patterns. This limitation is viewed as a narrow application for a technology perceived to have significant potential. The need for a more comprehensive exploration of this technology's capabilities is emphasized, suggesting that the development community should evaluate multiple script enhancements and avoid narrowing their focus on any particular proposal that only partially addresses the broader potential of commitment hashes.
In essence, the email reflects a call to action for the Bitcoin development community to delve deeper into the possibilities offered by commitment hashes and to consider a wider range of applications and enhancements to fully leverage this technology.
